content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <catalog-item>    <common-information>       <cat-id>3482</cat-id>       <cat-type-code>PRJ</cat-type-code>       <metadata-workflow-state>Published / External</metadata-workflow-state>       <is-do-not-publish>N</is-do-not-publish>       <name>Recreational Statistics</name>       <title>Recreational Fisheries Statistics</title>       <abstract>The receational fisheries statstics team of the Fisheries Statistics Division of the Office of Science and Technology collect data on recreationally-caught species from marine and estuarine waters.  The programs cover inland and ocean fisheries from shore and boat, including for-hire.  Recreational data are generated through statistics methods to procedures, rather than census.</abstract>       <purpose>Provide the detailed, timely, scientifically sound estimates that fisheries managers, stock assessors and marine scientists need to ensure the sustainability of ocean resources.</purpose>       <notes/>       <supplemental-info/> <meaning>Marine Recreational Information Program</meaning>       </acronym>    </acronyms>    <glossary-terms/>    <faqs/>    <downloads/>    <related-items>       <item cat-id="20718" cat-type="PRJ" relation-type="HI">          <title>Highly Migratory Species Catch Card Census Program (HMS-CC)</title>          <abstract>NOAA Fisheries has a rule in place that requires mandatory reporting of all recreationally landed billfish, swordfish, and bluefin tuna. In all but two states these species are reported by HMS anglers and captains either online or by phone. In Maryland and North Carolina this requirement is fulfilled by participation in Catch Card Census programs.  </abstract>       </item>       <item cat-id="20721" cat-type="PRJ" relation-type="HI">          <title>Large Pelagics Survey (LPS)</title>          <abstract>The Large Pelagics Survey (LPS) is specifically designed to collect information on recreational fishing directed at large pelagic species (e.g., tunas, billfishes, swordfish, sharks, wahoo, dolphin, and amberjack).  Offshore trips targeting large pelagics typically make up a relatively small proportion of all recreational fishing trips.  Using this specialized survey design allows for higher levels of sampling large pelagic trips, which ultimately improves estimates of catch and effort for large pelagics.   The LPS has been conducted since 1992 from Maine through Virginia.  The LPS includes two independent, complementary surveys which provide the effort and average catch per trip estimates needed to estimate total catch by species. </abstract>       </item>       <item cat-id="10906" cat-type="PRJ" relation-type="HI">          <title>Marine Recreational Information Program (MRIP)</title>          <abstract>The Marine Recreational Information Program, or MRIP, is the new way NOAA Fisheries is counting and reporting marine recreational catch and effort. It is a customer-driven initiative that will not only produce better estimates, but will do so through a process grounded in the principles of transparency, accountability and engagement. MRIP replaces the Marine Recreational Fisheries Statistics Survey, or MRFSS, which has been in place since the 1970s.</abstract>       </item>    </related-items>    <fgdc-contacts>
